title: coronavirus rising different countries uk among countries seefastest
story: Most of the countries are in Europe – 11 in total, including the UK, France and Germany. Belgium, the Netherlands and Sweden have seen the highest rate of increase over the last week, with cases in Belgium surging by over 3,000 per cent in seven days.As of last Monday, Belgium had just seven active coronavirus cases – but that figure had leaped to 238 as of Monday.The UK saw the fourth-highest increase in cases over the last week, according to data recorded by Johns Hopkins University. There were 299 active coronavirus cases in Britain on Monday, up from 32 at the start of last week – an increase of 834 per cent over the seven days. It took four days for the UK's number of cases to last double, from 106 on March 5 to 299 on March 9, putting the country in the middle of the pack in terms of the doubling rate of the virus.This is less than the rate of increase in Spain, where active cases have doubled in just two days. There, 460 people were said to have the virus, but that had increase to 1,013 on Monday.The doubling rate is, however, lower in countries in which the virus is already more established and has infected more people. In Japan and South Korea, for example, it took coronavirus nine days to last double its number of active cases.The countries with the highest number of recorded active cases as of Monday were China (18,880), Italy (7,985) and South Korea (7,307).It is important to note that other countries may have higher undetected cases because the official numbers are reliant upon rigorous testing and data collection methods in each country.The number of active cases in China – and in Hubei province, the epicentre of the virus – has fallen over the last week. Hubei has seen active cases drop by 40 per cent since last Monday, while in China the number has dropped by 67 per cent.While cases are still rising in South Korea, the country's rate of growth has slowed with cases currently doubling every nine days. The most concerning trajectory is in Italy, which has the second highest number of confirmed active cases and is currently seeing that number double every three days. The main goal for the UK Government as it faces coronavirus is to contain and delay it – part of its four-point contain, delay, research and mitigate strategy.This timeline is defined by the likely progress of an outbreak in five scenarios as it moves across Europe, and is taken from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), the EU's main public health body. But looking at case data from across Europe, it's clear that different European countries are at different stages of this strategy – and with different levels of success.Most countries managed to delay major surges in cases for at least 20 days as the number of infections in Europe remained low.Daily data sourced from the World Health Organisation and compiled by John Hopkins University shows that some of the worst affected countries were able to contain the disease for weeks.In Italy, the first substantial increase in active cases (533 per cent) did not occur for 21 days after the country had detected its first case. The UK is following a similar trajectory, with a 400 per cent increase in active cases after 24 days.Countries detecting the virus later appear to be less successful in keeping numbers low. In Austria, Switzerland, Norway and the Netherlands, the virus was detected for the first time less than two weeks ago. But once it was present, each country saw the number of confirmed cases double – or even triple – in the first three days.Francois Balloux, a professor of computational systems biology at University College London, told The  he thought it likely that the UK would follow the same pattern as Italy over the coming weeks.The trajectory of the epidemic in the UK is so far roughly comparable to the one in Northern Italy, but with the epidemic in northern Italy two to three weeks ahead of the situation in the UK, he said.The above graphic shows the speed at which cases increased in Italy. While lagging in total numbers, confirmed cases in the UK have doubled roughly once every three days in the last week, suggesting that Britain is on much the same track.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: nadine dorries infected coronavirus
story: Public health officials are seeking to trace anyone who has been in contact with Nadine Dorries after it emerged that the health minister had contracted coronavirus.Her boss Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, may have to be tested if he displays symptoms.Ms Dorries, who has met hundreds of people as part of her duties, became ill last Friday but was not confirmed to have the virus until Monday evening. As officials scrambled to trace people who may have been in contact with her, Public Health England said it had assessed the risk of her inidual close contacts and only those with symptoms needed to self-isolate.One of those is the Labour MP Rachael Maskell, who has been advised to self-isolate after a meeting with Ms Dorries last Thursday. But Downing Street sources say Boris Johnson was not in close contact with his health minister and has not shown any symptoms.Ms Dorries has been working in Parliament and the Department of Health and Social Care for the past week, and on Thursday attended a Downing Street event with the Prime Minister.Experts believe people infected with the virus can carry it for up to five days before symptoms emerge. Ms Dorries, 62, started feeling ill on Friday as she was signing a statutory instrument that declared coronavirus to be a notifiable disease, enabling companies to obtain insurance cover. The health minister held a surgery in her Mid Bedfordshire constituency on Saturday, attended by 50 people, and over the weekend experienced the classic symptoms of the disease – a dry cough, high temperature and vice-like pain in her chest.A government source said: As with everything, we are being guided by the science on this. This will be treated like any other standard case. Officials are conducting the standard process of contact tracing and identifying anyone who has shown symptoms.A health department source said: We are lucky in the timing, because Matt last saw Nadine last Wednesday and her symptoms only came on at the back end of the week. Matt has no symptoms, and therefore is okay.Nadine self-isolated on Saturday, so over the weekend it's hoped all traces were gone. We know Nadine was in Number 10 last week, but it is not certain how much contact she had with the PM. You have to be within two metres for more than 20 minutes.The disclosure will raise concerns about whether Parliament needs to be curtailed. Earlier this week, the parliamentary authorities decided against taking action to either restrict access to Parliament or close it down. Mr Hancock said it should stay open because scrutiny is incredibly important during the outbreak.The decision was due to be reviewed early next week. Chris Whitty, the chief medical officer for England, has warned elderly peers and MPs that they may be told to stay at home for their own protection.On Tuesday night, the leader of the House of Commons, Jacob Rees-Mogg, said there were no current plans to shut down parliament. Parliamentary authorities are already taking advice from the chief medical officer and will continue to do so, he said.Sources said the feeling inside Number 10 was that Parliament needed to be kept open. One Cabinet minister said: There's a feeling at all levels that Parliament needs to remain operational to pass the PM's emergency legislation and the finance bill.Ms Dorries is understood to be over the worst and recovering well. She tweeted: Thanks for so many good wishes. It's been pretty rubbish, but I hope I'm over the worst of it now. More worried about my 84yo mum who is staying with me and began with the cough today.She is being tested tomorrow. Keep safe and keep washing those hands, everyone.A Government source said: The PHE (Public Health England) contract tracers are doing their work. They will identify who needs to self-isolate or be tested and take it from there.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: 2020 democrat primaries joe biden projected win mississippi
story: Joe Biden took a commanding lead in the Democratic presidential nomination race last night, winning four states and triggering calls for Bernie Sanders to end his campaign. The former US vice president was projected to take Mississippi, Missouri, Idaho and Michigan, a state Mr Sanders won in the 2016 race, handing him a sizable delegate lead.The two other states which went to the polls on so-called Super Tuesday Two, Washington and North Dakota, remained too close to call at 1am US east coast time. The victories underscored Mr Biden’s vast support among the African-American community but also showed he could compete among white working class voters whose backing Mr Sanders has touted.The results made Mr Sanders’s path to the nomination even narrower, given Mr Biden’s widened lead in delegates - the metric that will determine the winner - and tough states coming up next in the next round of voting on Tuesday.  Mr Biden, speaking near his campaign headquarters in Philadelphia after cancelling a rally in Ohio due to coronavirus concerns, gave a pared back address as he chose to embrace Mr Sanders and call for unity rather than attack his rival. “I want to thank Bernie Sanders and his supporters for their tireless energy and their passion. We share a common goal, and together, we’ll defeat Donald Trump,” said Mr Biden, who will need Sanders supporters on side should he become the nominee and fight the November election. Speaking from a teleprompter, Mr Biden also repeatedly talked about the need to unify, saying: “Winning means uniting America, not sowing more ision and anger. It means not only having a president who knows how to fight but knows how to heal.” After the event Biden campaign staffers, who had made up the audience for the speech thanks to the late switch of venue, danced wildly to music and chanted “Let’s Go Joe!” as they celebrated the victories. By contrast Mr Sanders, in a sign of disappointment at the early outcomes, took the unusual step of not speaking publicly on results night. He was at home in Vermont after also cancelling an Ohio event due to coronavirus fears. His national press secretary, Briahna Joy Gray, insisted Mr Sanders would appear at the debate against Mr Biden on Sunday, with another four states to vote next Tuesday, but there was little public comment from the campaign.  Mr Sanders has repeatedly said he will back whoever wins the nomination and this weekend played down the likelihood of continuing in the race if there was no path to victory. High profile Democratic moderates including Bill Clinton’s former campaign manager James Carville and South Carolina congressman Jim Clyburn urged him to drop out on Tuesday evening. “Let’s shut this puppy down,” said Mr Carville. “Let’s move on and worry about November. This thing is decided, there’s no reason to keep it going, not even a day longer.”Andrew Yang, the former contender for the Democratic nomination who backed Mr Sanders in 2016, announced live on CNN he would be endorsing Mr Biden, saying: “The math says Joe is our prohibitive nominee.”Despite more than half the 50 states in America still to vote, Mr Sanders’s path to the White House is less clear after the results, with many of the states voting next Tuesday ones he failed to win in the 2016 race. However at a results watch party for Mr Sanders’s supporters at the Anchor Bar in Detroit, Michigan there was defiance and frustration among his fans. One volunteer, James, said he had travelled all the way from Oakland, California to spend two weeks knocking on doors for Mr Sanders in Michigan.He rejected the idea that Mr Sanders should drop out of the race, saying: Biden will never form the social contract the way that Bernie will.” Cheryl Herrman, another volunteer, shook her head when asked if she would back Mr Biden should he become the nominee, pointing to past comments he had made about segregationists. Early in the night a local campaign official stood up to thank volunteers for their efforts, saying: “I want you all to remember that this movement is not about a ballot box.” The night underscored Mr Biden’s remarkable primaries turnaround. A fortnight ago he had never won a state in his three White House bids stretching back three decades. He has now notched up more than a dozen victories. That surge, which aides dubbed “the Biden bounce back”, had been triggered by a strong performance in South Carolina combined with a flurry of endorsements from moderate rivals who dropped out of the race. Mr Biden’s vast support among the African-American community was apparent again on Tuesday, winning 87 per cent to Mr Sanders’s 10 per cent with black voters in Mississippi.In Michigan, Mr Sanders dropped support across the board with white voters compared to his 2016 performance., underscoring the limits of his voter coalition. Mr Sanders, effectively in a head-to head battle with Mr Biden, needed victories to show his bid would not be swept aside by “Joementum”. Instead early in the night he lost Michigan, a state he beat Hillary Clinton in during the 2016 race.Mr Biden had secured more than 800 delegates by 1am US east coast time while Mr Sanders was yet to reach 700. The first to 1,991 delegates wins the nomination. Tulsi Gabbard, the Hawaii congresswoman who remains in the race despite barely breaking through with Democratic voters, again made little dent in the contests on Tuesday. Mr Trump stayed largely quiet on the Democratic race on Twitter as results came through but around 1am he tweeted accusing Elizabeth Warren of having “totally destroyed the campaign of Bernie Sanders” by not dropping out earlier.  More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: joe biden crushed bernie sanders revolution
story: Two weeks is an eternity in politics. Just ask Bernie Sanders.It was only that long ago he was cruising to the Democrat presidential nomination, and very possibly the White House.The prospect of America becoming a democratic socialist country was real.But US elections can turn on a dime, and that’s what happened in 2020.It wasn’t so much what went wrong for Mr Sanders. His rallies are still huge. He has suffered no major scandal.Instead, it was what went right for Joe Biden. It started when South Carolina voted on Feb 29, and the state's black population backed the former vice president en masse.Over the next few days centrist candidates dropped out and united behind Mr Biden, propelling him to victory on Super Tuesday. It all happened so quickly Mr Sanders was left reeling.He responded with a frenzy. On Sunday, Mr Sanders achieved the rare feat of appearing on all five major US political chat shows. His campaign fired out negative TV adverts against Mr Biden.But on Tuesday night he was trounced, by more than expected, in the southern states of Mississippi and Missouri.Then, Mr Sanders lost Michigan, the industrial rust belt state he had taken against Hillary Clinton four years earlier.It was a hammer blow, a potentially fatal one, for the Sanders campaign. Any Democrat running against Donald Trump in November would have to win Michigan.It showed, once and for all, that Mr Sanders' revolution is not happening, or at least not on the scale he needed it to.In state after state, so far, there has been no explosion in voter turnout.There has been no horde of factory workers uniting around the promise of government-funded universal healthcare.And no flood of millennials raised from their sofas on voting day by the prospect of free college tuition under a Sanders administration.In Michigan, Mr Sanders did win 82 per cent of voters aged under 30. But there simply weren't enough of them. They were swept away by a grey tide of over-65s backing Mr Biden.Mr Sanders failed, in the end, to conquer the apathy of the young.An additional blow came as anecdotal evidence in Michigan suggested Elizabeth Warren's supporters had sided with Mr Biden.Ms Warren, a standard bearer for the Democrats's progressive wing, dropped out after Super Tuesday.It would have seemed natural for her to endorse her friend Mr Sanders, but she decided to back no-one immediately.Exit polls also showed that many Democrat voters, including some of Mr Sanders' own supporters, believe the time has come to unify the party.Their overwhelming motivation is to defeat Mr Trump, and many appear to have decided that Mr Biden has the best chance.For Mr Sanders, there is no way to tack his policies to the prevailing wind. They are set in stone.In a week's time several other large states vote including Florida, where he is now 40 points behind Mr Biden in polls.It is becoming increasingly difficult to see a rationale for him to go on.His only realistic hope lies in a debate with Mr Biden on Sunday.It will be the first one-on-one encounter between the two men, and Mr Sanders is widely considered the stronger debater.He will use it to make a final argument that the Democrats should pick a nominee who represents the starkest contrast to Mr Trump.Mr Sanders will need to not only win the debate, but eviscerate Mr Biden, if the race is to continue.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: coronavirus budget 2020 business rates
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The Government has abolished business rates for thousands of small firms as part of emergency measures to deal with the economic fallout from the coronavirus.Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a £30bn stimulus package including cutting business rates to zero this year for companies' with rateable values below £51,000.Firms will not have to pay any business rates on nearly half of all commercial properties, Mr Sunak said in his Budget speech. Pubs will see the discount they receive on business rates increased from £1,000 to £5,000.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFollow live updates on the BudgetThe chancellor&nbspalso announced a review into the long-term future of business rates, a tax which has been blamed for damaging UK high streets by burdening struggling firms with large bills that online competitors do not face.Cash grants of up to £3,000 will be made available to 700,000 small firms that already do not pay business rates.&nbspCompanies with less than 250 staff will also receive funding totalling up to £2bn&nbspto cover the cost of sick pay during the outbreak.Mr Sunak announced statutory sick pay would available for all of those advised to self isolate during the outbreak, even if they do not have symptoms. This will not extend to zero hours workers or those who are self employed.Instead, millions of gig economy workers will be given help through a £500m boost to the benefits system, including a temporary halt to the minimum floor in universal credit and quicker payments for employment and support allowance (ESA) claimants.£500m Budget boost for self-employed workers hit by coronavirusMr Sunak claimed the coronavirus response measures amounted to one of the most comprehensive economic responses of any government anywhere in the world to date.The government pledged to invest an extra £175bn&nbspover the next five years in a move that will boost economic output by 0.5 per cent, according to the Office for Budget Responsibility.Included in that figure will be an increase in spending on research and development to £22bn a year. The increase will take R&ampD spending to its highest level as a proportion of GDP for almost 40 years, the chancellor said.Tom Leman, head of retail and consumer at law firm Pinsent Masons,&nbspsaid: “The abolition of business rates for small to medium sized retailers and restaurants will be extremely welcome news.On the basis the corona virus is not a long term issue for these businesses it is crucial that they have the liquidity to see them through the worst.This will definitely help the cause and hopefully see many of them come out the other side ready to benefit from the increased spending power prompted by the money people are currently saving on their discretionary spend.”Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus face mask n25 shortage symptoms
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.In some countries, including Japan and Germany, doctors are being told to reuse the single mask they get daily because of a lack of supplyMichael Einhorn’s medical supply company may run out of the masks used to protect against coronavirus in two weeks unless the Chinese manufacturer of his branded equipment resumes production this week.“We’re having to make tough decisions every day on who gets masks and who doesn’t,” said Einhorn, the founder of New York-based Dealmed-Park Surgical, which employs almost 100 people. “Do masks go to the suburban hospital or the 911 responders? It’s a huge responsibility, and we know we’re going to make some mistakes.”Einhorn’s dilemma is playing out on a global stage. With the deadly virus now present in 100 countries, companies are unable to match demand for the masks needed by health workers. That’s led governments to jockey for supplies, including the US, which is stockpiling, and Germany and South Korea, which banned exports of masks altogether.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPublic health officials are warning that restrictive trade measures tied to medical supplies could worsen the shortfall and risk making poorer nations more vulnerable to the coronavirus’ spread.In some countries, including Japan and Germany, doctors are being told to reuse the single mask they get daily because of a lack of supply.Created with Sketch.Airports empty as Coronavirus affects aviation industry Show all 11Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.711 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China1011 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China711 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China1011 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China“Most places are not prepared, so you now have a cascade of countries putting these export bans in place,” said Stephen Morrison, director of the Global Health Policy Center at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. “It’s not a long-term solution. Everyone throwing up export bans isn’t going to solve the problem of how you will get the products in time to serve these acute needs.”Peter Navarro, one of President Donald Trump’s trade advisers, met last week with a group of pharmaceutical companies to discuss supply chain vulnerabilities and ways to ensure that critical parts of the drug supply chain could move away from China -- or better, back to the U.S., people familiar with the meeting told Bloomberg. Navarro didn’t respond to requests for comment.Manufacturers need to boost production of masks by another 40 per cent&nbspto meet demand, said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the World Health Organization’s director general. While the WHO has shipped supplies to 47 countries including Iran, Cambodia and Uganda, shortages will hit soon, especially of the N95 masks that block out 95 per cent&nbspof airborne particulates to combat the current virus.“Industry and governments must act quickly to boost supply, ease export restrictions and put measures in place to stop speculation and hoarding,” Tedros said in a statement 3 March. “We can’t stop Covid-19 without protecting health workers first,” he said, referring to the illness caused by the virus.Despite Tedros’ appeal, South Korea, Germany and Russia announced export bans of masks and other protective gear days after. They join others nation or territories including India, Taiwan, Thailand, and Kazakhstan that earlier put export bans in place. The novel coronavirus has now spread to more than 113,000 cases globally and killed over 3,900 people.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailPublic health experts are concerned that should more developed countries ban exports of masks and protective gear, poorer nations could be at risk of widening outbreaks, particularly among medical workers.“It will paralyze and freeze up the market,” said Morrison of CSIS. “The accumulated impact of these measures is to create paralysis -- one big logjam.”Trump ‘fretting over coronavirus’ as Biden opens up huge poll leadExport bans and other measures adopted by developed countries risk deepening global isions over the virus, said Lawrence Gostin, director of the O’Neill Institute for National and Global Health Law at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.“It would entirely unravel global cooperation if Covid-19 turned into a major killer, and we see hundreds of thousands deaths in lower income countries with relatively few deaths in the global north,” said Gostin, who is also the director of the WHO’s Collaborating Center on Public Health Law &amp Human Rights.Before the epidemic, China produced about half of the world’s output of masks with daily production of about 20 million units, according to state media Xinhua. Factories have since boosted production more than five-fold and are enlisting carmakers to manufacture them. That’s still not enough.In the US, increased efforts by mask makers 3M Co. and DuPont De Nemours Inc. are also falling short of demand. DuPont, which makes masks and protective body suits worn by first responders, said it’s increased production by more than three times its usual global capacity. 3M, the biggest American manufacturer of N95 respirators, has increased production since the outbreak in China.“We’ve added staff, we’ve added overtime, we’ve added technology, we’ve been increasing manufacturing lines,” said 3M spokeswoman Jennifer Ehrlich. “We expect this demand for respirators and other supplies to continue to outpace supply for the foreseeable future.”The dependence on China and a few other countries for masks has some calling for a rethink of supply chains. The World Medical Association, which represents physicians, wants governments to establish factories in major markets like the European Union and the U.S. to ensure adequate supply of critical drugs, vaccines and other medical necessities.The US only has about 1 per cent of the 3.5 billion masks it needs to combat a serious outbreak, Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar has said. The country plans to buy 500 million surgical masks and N95 respirators for the national stockpile.Einhorn of Dealmed thinks the shortage isn’t likely to let up until the summer. The crisis may finally convince Americans to pay more for masks made in the US, he said. Dealmed is seeking bids for domestically-produced equipment.“The world shouldn’t be relying on one country for health care products,” Einhorn said. “We absolutely need to look at the supply chain.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus latest eurozone recession morgan stanley berenberg forecasts
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Eurozone economy to shrink in first half of 2020, banks forecast as virus spreadsCoronavirus is pushing Europe into recession as the rapidly spreading outbreak takes a heavy toll on businesses and consumer confidence, economists have warned.Investment banks Morgan Stanley and Berenberg both expect the Eurozone’s economy to shrink in the first half of&nbsp2020. They issued new forecasts on Monday amid the worst meltdown in global markets since the 2008 financial crash.Berenberg projected the Eurozone’s GDP to fall by 0.4 per cent in the first three months of the year and 0.5 per cent in the second quarter.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAnalysts said the sweeping month-long lockdown imposed by Italy, the zone’s third largest economy, on 16 million people “goes beyond the disruptions we had anticipated”.“The Italian measures — and the possibility that other parts of Europe may move in the same direction in coming weeks — are likely to weigh significantly further on confidence in the near term,” said Holger Schmieding, chief economist at the German bank.Created with Sketch.Airports empty as Coronavirus affects aviation industry Show all 11Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.711 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China1011 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China711 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China1011 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, ChinaThe bank predicted Italy’s economy would contract by 1.2 per cent by the end of the 2020, and said its forecasts for the next few months would be “shaped much more by the coronavirus epidemic than by economic fundamentals or shifts in monetary or fiscal policy”.France’s central bank said it expected the country’s economy to barely grow in the first quarter of the year, cutting its GDP forecast from 0.3 per cent 0.1 per cent.Coronavirus could tip Europe into recession, OECD warnsThe country’s finance minister, Bruno Le Maire, said Europe needed a “call to arms” to defend the already weakened economy from an outbreak that has disrupted companies’ supply chains, forced airlines to cut capacity and prompted shoppers in some countries to stockpile food.The downbeat assessments made for a grim start to the week for European Central Bank (ECB) policymakers, who will meet in Frankfurt this week and may be forced to lower interest rates and step up bond purchases. The US Federal Reserve has already acted, with an unexpected easing last week.The ECB told most of its 3,500-plus staff to work from home on Monday to test how it could cope with a coronavirus shutdown. It has cancelled most of its public events over the next month but said its rate-setting Governing Council meeting would go ahead as scheduled on Thursday.The turmoil in global markets on Monday was deepened by&nbspan all-out oil price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia, which has led to stocks and oil prices tanking around the world.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: french connection revenue loss coronavirus uk high street
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The retailer’s performance has not been helped by ‘potential uncertainty due to the&nbspCovid-19&nbspcoronavirus’, says Stephen MarksFrench Connection slid to a loss last year as the gloom on UK high streets took its toll.The fashion&nbspretailer missed its guidance for the year after trading in the second half was “considerably worse than expected” following a poor festive period.It said revenue fell 11.4 per cent to £119.9m for the 12 months to 31 January as it was weighed down by store closures and “the difficult retail trading environment”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesChairman and chief executive Stephen Marks said the company’s performance “has not been as anticipated” and the business has not been assisted by “potential uncertainty due to the Covid-19 coronavirus”.French Connection slipped to an underlying loss of £2.9m during the year, from an £800,000 profit in the previous year.It said like-for-like sales continued to decline in the UK and Europe, falling 2.5 per cent over the period.The company said it has also been hit by its closure programme, which saw 11 high street stores, three outlets, and four concessions shut their doors.It also took a £500,000 hit from the closure of its joint venture in Hong Kong and China.Shoppers return to UK high streets after dire 2019 tradingWe miss the high-street shops – but only when they’ve goneSystem allowing contactless payments to homeless people trialledHand sanitisers selling online for 50 times their retail priceHowever, the company said it was pleased with the “continued good performance” of its wholesale business in the US and has good forward orders in the UK, to be delivered during the first half of the year.Mr Marks said: “We believe the trading landscape in the UK is unlikely to improve in the short term and this has a potential impact on both the retail and wholesale businesses.“Against this background, we are working hard to ensure we are operating as efficiently and cost-effectively as possible while working closely with all our trading partners to maximise business with them.”Shares in the company tumbled 8.5 per cent to 16.9p in early trading on Tuesday.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'In the absence of an early and smooth transition to a net-zero economy, the risks of a delayed but abrupt transition will rise,'&nbspsays Bank of England governorMany fossil fuel assets will not be viable if companies and countries keep their commitments to reach net-zero emissions, Mark Carney has warned.The Bank of England governor pointed to the precipitous decline of America’s coal industry as a possible sign of things to come for other fossil fuel producers if they do not prepare properly for a low-carbon future.The combined value of the top four US coal producers has fallen by more than 99 per cent since 2010 as the dirty fuel faces becoming obsolete.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“In the absence of an early and smooth transition to a net-zero economy, the risks of a delayed but abrupt transition will rise,” Mr Carney said&nbspin a letter to the Treasury Select Committee.“This could precipitate a sharp reassessment of asset values and of climate risks, destabilise markets, spark a pro-cyclical crystallisation of losses, leading to persistent tightening of financial conditions: a climate Minsky moment.”Created with Sketch.Climate change: Decade's defining issue in pictures Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.In this decade, humans have become ever more aware of climate change. Calls for leaders to act echo around the globe as the signs of a changing climate become ever more difficult to ignoreFierce wildfires have flared up in numerous countries. The damage being caused is unprecedented: 103 people were killed in wildfires last year in California, one of the places best prepared, best equipped to fight such blazes in the worldEntire towns have been razed. The towns of Redding and Paradise in California were all but eliminated in the 2018 seasonWhile wildfires in Greece (pictured), Australia, Indonesia and many other countries have wrought chaos to infrastructure, economies and cost livesIn Britain, flooding has become commonplace. Extreme downpours in Carlisle in the winter of 2015 saw the previous record flood level being eclipsed by two feetHebden Bridge in West Yorkshire has flooded repeatedly in the past decade, with the worst coming on Christmas Day 2015. Toby Smith of Climate Visuals, an organisation focused on improving how climate change is depicted in the media, says: Extreme weather and flooding, has and will become more frequent due to climate change. An increase in the severity and distribution of press images, reports and media coverage across the nation has localised the issue. It has raised our emotions, perception and personalised the effects and hazards of climate change.Out west in Somerset, floods in 2013 led to entire villages being cut off and isolated for weeksIn summer 2012, intense rain flooded over 8000 properties. In 2013, storms and coastal surges combined catastrophically with elevated sea levels whilst December 2015, was the wettest month ever recorded. Major flooding events continued through the decade with the UK government declaring flooding as one of the nation's major threats in 2017,  says Mr Smith of Climate VisualsWeather has been more extreme in Britain in recent years. title: coronavirus budget 2020 business rates
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The Government has abolished business rates for thousands of small firms as part of emergency measures to deal with the economic fallout from the coronavirus.Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a £30bn stimulus package including cutting business rates to zero this year for companies' with rateable values below £51,000.Firms will not have to pay any business rates on nearly half of all commercial properties, Mr Sunak said in his Budget speech. Pubs will see the discount they receive on business rates increased from £1,000 to £5,000.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFollow live updates on the BudgetThe chancellor&nbspalso announced a review into the long-term future of business rates, a tax which has been blamed for damaging UK high streets by burdening struggling firms with large bills that online competitors do not face.Cash grants of up to £3,000 will be made available to 700,000 small firms that already do not pay business rates.&nbspCompanies with less than 250 staff will also receive funding totalling up to £2bn&nbspto cover the cost of sick pay during the outbreak.Mr Sunak announced statutory sick pay would available for all of those advised to self isolate during the outbreak, even if they do not have symptoms. This will not extend to zero hours workers or those who are self employed.Instead, millions of gig economy workers will be given help through a £500m boost to the benefits system, including a temporary halt to the minimum floor in universal credit and quicker payments for employment and support allowance (ESA) claimants.£500m Budget boost for self-employed workers hit by coronavirusMr Sunak claimed the coronavirus response measures amounted to one of the most comprehensive economic responses of any government anywhere in the world to date.The government pledged to invest an extra £175bn&nbspover the next five years in a move that will boost economic output by 0.5 per cent, according to the Office for Budget Responsibility.Included in that figure will be an increase in spending on research and development to £22bn a year. The increase will take R&ampD spending to its highest level as a proportion of GDP for almost 40 years, the chancellor said.Tom Leman, head of retail and consumer at law firm Pinsent Masons,&nbspsaid: “The abolition of business rates for small to medium sized retailers and restaurants will be extremely welcome news.On the basis the corona virus is not a long term issue for these businesses it is crucial that they have the liquidity to see them through the worst.This will definitely help the cause and hopefully see many of them come out the other side ready to benefit from the increased spending power prompted by the money people are currently saving on their discretionary spend.”Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus face mask n25 shortage symptoms
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.In some countries, including Japan and Germany, doctors are being told to reuse the single mask they get daily because of a lack of supplyMichael Einhorn’s medical supply company may run out of the masks used to protect against coronavirus in two weeks unless the Chinese manufacturer of his branded equipment resumes production this week.“We’re having to make tough decisions every day on who gets masks and who doesn’t,” said Einhorn, the founder of New York-based Dealmed-Park Surgical, which employs almost 100 people. “Do masks go to the suburban hospital or the 911 responders? It’s a huge responsibility, and we know we’re going to make some mistakes.”Einhorn’s dilemma is playing out on a global stage. With the deadly virus now present in 100 countries, companies are unable to match demand for the masks needed by health workers. That’s led governments to jockey for supplies, including the US, which is stockpiling, and Germany and South Korea, which banned exports of masks altogether.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPublic health officials are warning that restrictive trade measures tied to medical supplies could worsen the shortfall and risk making poorer nations more vulnerable to the coronavirus’ spread.In some countries, including Japan and Germany, doctors are being told to reuse the single mask they get daily because of a lack of supply.Created with Sketch.Airports empty as Coronavirus affects aviation industry Show all 11Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.711 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China1011 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China711 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China1011 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China“Most places are not prepared, so you now have a cascade of countries putting these export bans in place,” said Stephen Morrison, director of the Global Health Policy Center at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. “It’s not a long-term solution. Everyone throwing up export bans isn’t going to solve the problem of how you will get the products in time to serve these acute needs.”Peter Navarro, one of President Donald Trump’s trade advisers, met last week with a group of pharmaceutical companies to discuss supply chain vulnerabilities and ways to ensure that critical parts of the drug supply chain could move away from China -- or better, back to the U.S., people familiar with the meeting told Bloomberg. Navarro didn’t respond to requests for comment.Manufacturers need to boost production of masks by another 40 per cent&nbspto meet demand, said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the World Health Organization’s director general. While the WHO has shipped supplies to 47 countries including Iran, Cambodia and Uganda, shortages will hit soon, especially of the N95 masks that block out 95 per cent&nbspof airborne particulates to combat the current virus.“Industry and governments must act quickly to boost supply, ease export restrictions and put measures in place to stop speculation and hoarding,” Tedros said in a statement 3 March. “We can’t stop Covid-19 without protecting health workers first,” he said, referring to the illness caused by the virus.Despite Tedros’ appeal, South Korea, Germany and Russia announced export bans of masks and other protective gear days after. They join others nation or territories including India, Taiwan, Thailand, and Kazakhstan that earlier put export bans in place. The novel coronavirus has now spread to more than 113,000 cases globally and killed over 3,900 people.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailPublic health experts are concerned that should more developed countries ban exports of masks and protective gear, poorer nations could be at risk of widening outbreaks, particularly among medical workers.“It will paralyze and freeze up the market,” said Morrison of CSIS. “The accumulated impact of these measures is to create paralysis -- one big logjam.”Trump ‘fretting over coronavirus’ as Biden opens up huge poll leadExport bans and other measures adopted by developed countries risk deepening global isions over the virus, said Lawrence Gostin, director of the O’Neill Institute for National and Global Health Law at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.“It would entirely unravel global cooperation if Covid-19 turned into a major killer, and we see hundreds of thousands deaths in lower income countries with relatively few deaths in the global north,” said Gostin, who is also the director of the WHO’s Collaborating Center on Public Health Law &amp Human Rights.Before the epidemic, China produced about half of the world’s output of masks with daily production of about 20 million units, according to state media Xinhua. Factories have since boosted production more than five-fold and are enlisting carmakers to manufacture them. That’s still not enough.In the US, increased efforts by mask makers 3M Co. and DuPont De Nemours Inc. are also falling short of demand. DuPont, which makes masks and protective body suits worn by first responders, said it’s increased production by more than three times its usual global capacity. 3M, the biggest American manufacturer of N95 respirators, has increased production since the outbreak in China.“We’ve added staff, we’ve added overtime, we’ve added technology, we’ve been increasing manufacturing lines,” said 3M spokeswoman Jennifer Ehrlich. “We expect this demand for respirators and other supplies to continue to outpace supply for the foreseeable future.”The dependence on China and a few other countries for masks has some calling for a rethink of supply chains. The World Medical Association, which represents physicians, wants governments to establish factories in major markets like the European Union and the U.S. to ensure adequate supply of critical drugs, vaccines and other medical necessities.The US only has about 1 per cent of the 3.5 billion masks it needs to combat a serious outbreak, Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar has said. The country plans to buy 500 million surgical masks and N95 respirators for the national stockpile.Einhorn of Dealmed thinks the shortage isn’t likely to let up until the summer. The crisis may finally convince Americans to pay more for masks made in the US, he said. Dealmed is seeking bids for domestically-produced equipment.“The world shouldn’t be relying on one country for health care products,” Einhorn said. “We absolutely need to look at the supply chain.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus iphone launch cancel silicon valley california apple
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Apple events, sporting fixtures&nbspand more to be bannedLarge gatherings have been banned in the heart of Silicon Valley in an attempt to stop the spread of coronavirus, almost certainly affecting the launch of the next iPhone.Santa Clara County – which includes San Jose as well as many of the world's biggest tech company's headquarters – has said that gatherings of 1,000 people or more will not be allowed to happen.The announcement comes as the county announced its first death of a patient who had been diagnosed with COVID-19.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe woman was the third positive case in the area and the first to contract coronavirus without having travelled internationally or who was known to have been in contact with another infected person.The ban will mean that many of the world's biggest tech companies will be banned from holding large launch events from Wednesday and for the foreseeable future.What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?Latest travel updates as coronavirus continues to spreadCan face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The dirty truth about washing your handsThat almost certainly means that the launch of the next iPhone – the lower-cost iPhone 9, rumoured to be happening at the end of this month but which Apple is yet to announce – will be unable to go forward. Apple's annual WWDC event, which marks the highlight of its year for new software features and its developers, is also likely to be cancelled under the ban.Apple holds its new phone launches in its Steve Jobs Theater, which has a capacity of 1,000 and is usually fully packed.&nbspIt is very possible that Apple could launch the new phone without a large scale event, and it has released products with much smaller events or without a launch event at all in the past.Its Worldwide Developers Conference brings together more than 5,000 developers and as a consequence is even less likely to go ahead. That event has not yet been announced either but runs on an annual schedule, being held in San Jose every year.Previous reports have suggested that Apple's product pipeline – including the iPhone 12, which is expected much later in the year – could be affected by coronavirus, which is reducing both demand for new devices as well as the ability to supply enough models in time.It will also mean other major events such as sporting fixtures will no longer go ahead.The ban had been brought in to slow the spread of the disease, said&nbspSanta Clara County health officer&nbspSara Cody in a title: coronavirus latest eurozone recession morgan stanley berenberg forecasts
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Eurozone economy to shrink in first half of 2020, banks forecast as virus spreadsCoronavirus is pushing Europe into recession as the rapidly spreading outbreak takes a heavy toll on businesses and consumer confidence, economists have warned.Investment banks Morgan Stanley and Berenberg both expect the Eurozone’s economy to shrink in the first half of&nbsp2020. They issued new forecasts on Monday amid the worst meltdown in global markets since the 2008 financial crash.Berenberg projected the Eurozone’s GDP to fall by 0.4 per cent in the first three months of the year and 0.5 per cent in the second quarter.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAnalysts said the sweeping month-long lockdown imposed by Italy, the zone’s third largest economy, on 16 million people “goes beyond the disruptions we had anticipated”.“The Italian measures — and the possibility that other parts of Europe may move in the same direction in coming weeks — are likely to weigh significantly further on confidence in the near term,” said Holger Schmieding, chief economist at the German bank.Created with Sketch.Airports empty as Coronavirus affects aviation industry Show all 11Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.711 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China1011 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China711 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, China1011 Shanghai Pudong Airport in Shanghai, ChinaThe bank predicted Italy’s economy would contract by 1.2 per cent by the end of the 2020, and said its forecasts for the next few months would be “shaped much more by the coronavirus epidemic than by economic fundamentals or shifts in monetary or fiscal policy”.France’s central bank said it expected the country’s economy to barely grow in the first quarter of the year, cutting its GDP forecast from 0.3 per cent 0.1 per cent.Coronavirus could tip Europe into recession, OECD warnsThe country’s finance minister, Bruno Le Maire, said Europe needed a “call to arms” to defend the already weakened economy from an outbreak that has disrupted companies’ supply chains, forced airlines to cut capacity and prompted shoppers in some countries to stockpile food.The downbeat assessments made for a grim start to the week for European Central Bank (ECB) policymakers, who will meet in Frankfurt this week and may be forced to lower interest rates and step up bond purchases. The US Federal Reserve has already acted, with an unexpected easing last week.The ECB told most of its 3,500-plus staff to work from home on Monday to test how it could cope with a coronavirus shutdown. It has cancelled most of its public events over the next month but said its rate-setting Governing Council meeting would go ahead as scheduled on Thursday.The turmoil in global markets on Monday was deepened by&nbspan all-out oil price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia, which has led to stocks and oil prices tanking around the world.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The retailer’s performance has not been helped by ‘potential uncertainty due to the&nbspCovid-19&nbspcoronavirus’, says Stephen MarksFrench Connection slid to a loss last year as the gloom on UK high streets took its toll.The fashion&nbspretailer missed its guidance for the year after trading in the second half was “considerably worse than expected” following a poor festive period.It said revenue fell 11.4 per cent to £119.9m for the 12 months to 31 January as it was weighed down by store closures and “the difficult retail trading environment”.Sharing the full story, not just the Europe, falling 2.5 per cent over the period.The company said it has also been hit by its closure programme, which saw 11 high street stores, three outlets, and four concessions shut their doors.It also took a £500,000 hit from the closure of its joint venture in Hong Kong and China.Shoppers return to UK high streets after dire 2019 tradingWe miss the high-street shops – but only when they’ve story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'In the absence of an early and smooth transition to a net-zero economy, the risks of a delayed but abrupt transition will rise,'&nbspsays Bank of England governorMany fossil fuel assets will not be viable if companies and countries keep their commitments to reach net-zero emissions, Mark Carney has warned.The Bank of England governor pointed to the precipitous decline of America’s coal industry as a possible sign of things to come for other fossil fuel producers if they do not prepare properly for a low-carbon future.The combined value of the top four US coal producers has fallen by more than 99 per cent since 2010 as the dirty fuel faces becoming obsolete.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“In the absence of an early and smooth transition to a net-zero economy, the risks of a delayed but abrupt transition will rise,” Mr Carney said&nbspin a letter to the Treasury Select Committee.“This could precipitate a sharp reassessment of asset values and of climate risks, destabilise markets, spark a pro-cyclical crystallisation of losses, leading to persistent tightening of financial conditions: a climate Minsky moment.”Created with Sketch.Climate change: Decade's defining issue in pictures Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.In this decade, humans have become ever more aware of climate change. Calls for leaders to act echo around the globe as the signs of a changing climate become ever more difficult to ignoreFierce wildfires have flared up in numerous countries. The damage being caused is unprecedented: 103 people were killed in wildfires last year in California, one of the places best prepared, best equipped to fight such blazes in the worldEntire towns have been razed. The towns of Redding and Paradise in California were all but eliminated in the 2018 seasonWhile wildfires in Greece (pictured), Australia, Indonesia and many other countries have wrought chaos to infrastructure, economies and cost livesIn Britain, flooding has become commonplace. Extreme downpours in Carlisle in the winter of 2015 saw the previous record flood level being eclipsed by two feetHebden Bridge in West Yorkshire has flooded repeatedly in the past decade, with the worst coming on Christmas Day 2015. Toby Smith of Climate Visuals, an organisation focused on improving how climate change is depicted in the media, says: Extreme weather and flooding, has and will become more frequent due to climate change. An increase in the severity and distribution of press images, reports and media coverage across the nation has localised the issue. It has raised our emotions, perception and personalised the effects and hazards of climate change.Out west in Somerset, floods in 2013 led to entire villages being cut off and isolated for weeksIn summer 2012, intense rain flooded over 8000 properties. In 2013, storms and coastal surges combined catastrophically with elevated sea levels whilst December 2015, was the wettest month ever recorded. Major flooding events continued through the decade with the UK government declaring flooding as one of the nation's major threats in 2017,  says Mr Smith of Climate VisualsWeather has been more extreme in Britain in recent years. The 'Beast from the East' which arrived in February 2018 brought extraordinarily cold temperatures and high snowfall. Central London (pictured), where the city bustle tends to mean that snow doesn't even settle, was covered in inches of snow for dayMonths after the cold snap, a heatwave struck Britain, rendering the normally plush green of England's parks in Summer a parched brown for weeksWorsening droughts in many countries have been disastrous for crop yields and have threatened livestock. In Australia, where a brutal drought persisted for months last year, farmers have suffered from mental health problems because of the threat to their livelihoodEven dedicated climate skeptic Jeremy Clarkson has come to recognise the threat of climate change after visiting the Tonle Sap lake system in Cambodia. Over a million people rely on the water of Tonle Sap for work and sustinence but, as Mr Clarkson witnessed, a drought has severley depleted the water levelIn reaction to these harbingers of climate obliteration, some humans have taken measures to counter the impending disaster. Ethiopia recently planted a reported 350 million trees in a single day Morocco has undertaken the most ambitious solar power scheme in the world, recently completing a solar plant the size of San FranciscoElectric cars are taking off as a viable alternative to fossil fuel burning vehicles and major cities across the world are adding charging points to accomodateCities around the world are embracing cycling too, as a clean (and healthy) mode of transport. In December he warned that climate change could render some financial assets worthless.His latest comments come as momentum&nbspbuilds&nbspto tackle climate change among fund managers that invest in environmentally-damaging businesses.Carbon emissions falling at fastest rate in 30 yearsDespite these moves, it remains difficult for ordinary consumers to weigh up the climate impact of their pensions, savings and investments.MPs on the Treasury committee are seeking ways to make it clear to investors what risks climate change poses to their savings. title: matt lucas great british bake off noel fielding sandi toksvig new series channel 4
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Noel Fielding will return for the show’s next seriesMatt Lucas will replace Sandi Toskvig as the new co-host of The Great British Bake Off, it has been confirmed.The Little Britain star will host the forthcoming 11th series of the long-running hit show with Noel Fielding.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“I’m chuffed to bits to be joining the most delicious show on television,” Lucas said in a statement. “I can’t wait to break bread with Noel, Prue&nbsp{Leith} and Paul {Hollywood} and meet the brilliant bakers.“And bearing in mind my love of cake, I’ve already ordered some much larger trousers in anticipation.”Lucas added that it was his chemistry with Fielding that convinced Channel 4 to give him the job, explaining that they have it “by the oven load”.It’s clear early on that Jenny Eclair is this week’s GCBO winner Dave Bautista: ‘Fame is overwhelming – sometimes I want to hide’Why Andy Warhol thought ‘Trump is sort of cheap’Toksvig, who has hosted the series since its move to Channel 4 in 2017, announced in January that she was stepping down from the show to pursue other projects.“As my waistline will testify, Bake Off is an all-consuming show,” she said in a statement. “Spending time with Prue, Paul and Noel has been one of the great pleasures of my life. These are friendships which I know will continue beyond the confines of television.”It was reported last week (2 March) that Fielding was offered a £150,000 pay rise to convince him to stay on the show without Toksvig.Fielding previously expressed sadness over Toksvig’s departure, and admitted he now felt like “Tom without Jerry”.The Great Celebrity Bake Off, which returned last night (10 March), marks Toksvig’s final run on the series.Filming for the 11th series of Bake Off begins in the spring.The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.But Sunak stops short of extending sick pay to gig economy workersChancellor Rishi Sunak has announced £500m boost&nbspfor self-employed workers hit by coronavirus&nbsp- but stopped short of meeting demands to extend statutory sick pay to all.In his first Budget, Mr Sunak said statutory sick pay would&nbspavailable for all of those advised to self isolate during the outbreak, even if they do not have symptoms. This will not extend to zero hours workers or those who are self employed.Instead, millions of gig economy workers&nbspwill be given help through a £500m boost to the benefits system, including a temporary halt to&nbspthe minimum floor in universal credit and quicker payments for employment and support allowance (ESA) claimants.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThere will also be a £500m hardship fund for local authorities, Mr Sunak said, as he scrapped the need for claimants to attend job centre appointments in person.If people fall ill or can't work, we must support their finances. We must make sure that our safety net remains strong enough to fall back on, he told MPs.Sunak's first Budget to include billions for coronavirus responseSmall businesses will be given government help to meet the cost of statutory sick pay, the chancellor also announced.The looming economic hit from coronavirus dominated the Budget on Wednesday, with the chancellor admitting there was likely to be temporary disruption, with up to one in five workers expected to be off work at any one time.Mr Sunak said: I know how worried people are. Worried about their health, the health of their loved ones, their jobs, their income, their businesses, their financial security.And I know they get even more worried when they turn on their TVs and hear talk of markets collapsing and recessions coming. People want to know what's happening, and what can be done to fix it.What everyone needs to know is that we are doing everything we can to keep this country, and our people, healthy and financially secure.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: bernie sanders polling station line democratic primary michigan voter suppression
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Spectacle of people waiting four, five or six hours to vote augurs ill for fight against restrictive lawsBernie Sanders has raised the alarm about voting problems in the Michigan Democratic primary, demanding the state’s authorities make sure there are no obstacles to voting, and pointing to nationwide efforts at voter suppression.Mr Sanders tweeted his concern: “At a time when Democrats correctly attack Republicans for voter suppression, to see voters standing in long lines for hours in Michigan and around America is an outrage.“Election officials must address these problems immediately, and if necessary, keep polling places open longer.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Sanders’s state political co-ordinator, Abshir Omar, reported that one student voting at Michigan State University had waited for more than an hour to vote before giving up, saying “this is bulls**t, I can’t wait this long, I have to get to work”.Given the Democrats badly need to win Michigan in order to beat Donald Trump, the spectre of voting problems there has them deeply concerned.Texas man who waited six hours to vote Super Tuesday wasn’t eligibleHow voter suppression and fear sideline minorities in GeorgiaJudge blocks North Carolina voter ID law ahead of 2020 electionJust days before the 2016 election, the Michigan Democratic Party sued the Trump campaign, claiming it was engaged in efforts to intimidate and obstruct white liberals, young women and black voters. Similar lawsuits were filed in Arizona, Nevada, Ohio and Pennsylvania.Legal battles over voter access in Michigan continue to this day. One current battle in the state focuses on Republican-backed measures restricting organisers from helping people fill in absentee ballots or using a vehicle to transport them to the polls unless they cannot walk.Another state that has spent years making it harder to vote is Wisconsin, another crucial 2020 battlefield. Starting in 2010 under Republican governor Scott Walker, Wisconsin not only passed tough voter ID laws but restricted early voting hours, gerrymandered district boundaries in favour of Republicans and made it harder to register to vote.As with similar moves in other states, the measures have been criticised for targeting groups that tend to cast Democratic votes. In 2016, Hillary Clinton lost the state to Mr Trump by only 22,748 votes — less than 1 per cent.However, in good news for Democrats, a recent effort that would have thrown nearly 300,000 people off the state’s voter rolls was recently overturned in the Wisconsin Appeals Court.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe Democratic primary has seen serious pressure on the voting process in other states besides. In Texas, some voters were forced to wait in line for as long as five hours on Super Tuesday. Black and Latino neighbourhoods were disproportionately affected.&nbspDemocrats fear Trump could win enough Latino support to win electionThis is part of a pattern that’s playing out across the country. Democrats have for years been trying to expand the pool of swing states to include former Republican strongholds like Texas, Arizona and even Georgia. They are doing this by appealing to and organising the demographics where they do best — in particular with young people and black and Latino voters.Texas, still run by Republicans at the state level, is just one of several states to have reduced the number of polling stations and introduced strict voter ID laws. These measures have proliferated since a 2013 Supreme Court decision struck down a key provision of the Voting Rights Act that forced jurisdictions with a history of discrimination to seek approval before changing their laws.Among the states to have taken advantage of their new freedoms following the decision are several Republican-governed southern states with many black voters who tilt towards the Democrats.One law in North Carolina, which has lately been considered a swing state, was blocked by the Supreme Court in 2017 after a federal appeals court described it as an effort to “target African-Americans with almost surgical precision”.Unless the Democrats can overcome voter suppression efforts that target these groups, they will struggle to get on the front foot again.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: putin presidential term limit 2024 next russia president
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Loyal parliamentarians offer a convenient way for the president to stay on into his 80sVladimir Putin appears to have ended speculation about his intentions to remain in office by supporting a bid to reset presidential term limits.&nbspUnder current term limits, the Russian president would have been obliged to leave office in 2024, at the end of two consecutive terms. In January,&nbsphe proposed changing the constitution that would limit the presidency to two terms overall. On face value, that created additional barriers to Mr Putin staying on —&nbspthe solution favoured by most of Russia’s ruling class.&nbspOn Tuesday, parliamentarians offered a not-unexpected lifeline to their patron.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesValentina Tereshkova, a former cosmonaut and uber loyal deputy of the ruling party fraction in the State Duma, said changes should be dictated by the will of “the people.” But her opinion was clear: either the term limit should be removed, or reset for Mr Putin.&nbspSpeaker Vyacheslav Volodin convened a 90 minute pause in the parliamentary sitting to “discuss” the proposals. A short while later Mr Putin made the short trip over from the Kremlin to give his reaction.&nbspPutin has US 'exactly where he wants us', says key impeachment witnessTrump accused of threatening elections after interference warningAnyone near germaphobic Putin ‘temperature checked’ for coronavirusHe said he was open to the idea of a further two elections&nbsp—&nbspextending his tenure to his 80s, and comfortably past the previous record innings set by Joseph Stalin and Leonid Brezhnev.&nbsp“It’s a possible option in principle, but on one contrition: if the constitutional court decides that such an amendment will not contravene the constitution,” Mr Putin said. “We aren’t adopting a new constitution, but making significant amendments to it.”&nbspUnder the proposals Mr Putin put forward, appointments to the constitutional court are to be made by the president himself. This is one of several areas that will see presidential power increased.&nbspResetting presidential terms was seen by many experts as the most straightforward way for the president to get around his 2024 problem - but also the most cynical.&nbspIn 2011, Russian public opinion reacted strongly against a similarly transparent manoeuvre. Mr Putin’s return to office in place of Dmitry Medvedev was met with massive street protests that at one point threatened to spiral out of control.&nbspSpeaking at parliament, Mr Putin insisted his aim was to leave a democratic legacy. He would not support removing the term limit in entirety, for example.&nbsp“If the country is to be dynamic, it needs its leaders to change,” he said.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus uk n95 surgical face masks
story: The masks are generally used in industry, or to protect against poor air quality like in cities like Bejing.N masks are disposable face masks that are proven to filter the air to an industrial standard.Manufacturers y, but the N is a stamp from the US National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health to show that it is efficient, which comes with a logo.They are used to stop you from breathing in hazardous small particles, such as dust, mold or aerosol paint particles. They generally have an -hour shelf le before becoming clogged depending on the work youre doing.The general advice coming from medical professionals is that it couldnt hurt to use themyou do so properly, but that they are less effectivenot worn properly.The N stamp means that when subjected to careful testing, the respirator blocks at least  percent of . micronstest particles.The coronavirus molecule is . micronsby comparison.The major issue with the masks is that most people dont wear them the right way, compromising their efficiency.When applied correctly they will get hot and stuffy, so most people are likely to try and open them at the sides to breathe better, defeating the purpose.Manufacturers advise that it must cover both the nose and mouth to keep you from breathing in mold and dust. If it does not have a snug fit, it will not work properly.It will not work properly for people with beards or facial hair. Even one-day beard growth has been shown to let air leak in.Yes. There has been a lot of panic buying, particularly in Asia where people are handling a genuine threat from the virus.Infectious diseases expert at the Vanderbilt University’s Medical Center in Nashville, Tennessee, William Schaffner, said: “People want to find some way to bring some control to the situation, thus the scramble for face masks.”The shortage means that hundreds of online retailers are jacking up the price by up to  times market value in cities like Singapore.In the US and Canada, major retailers and medical suppliers are reporting shortages this week as people have started hoarding just in case.Hoarding behavior by those who do not exhibit respiratory symptoms has sparked concerns in medical circles that there could be a possible shortage of personal protective equipment in the coming weeks for those on the front lines who are actually being exposed to the virus.Experts are warning against hoarding in low-risk countries like Europe and the US where the virus is not prevalent.Annelies Wilder-Smith, a professor of emerging infectious diseases at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine said: “While we should take the outbreak seriously, we mustn’t panic and behave in a manner that is disproportionate to the threat we are confronted with.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
